repnme.cdata!: Egypt - Engineering and Technical Edcuation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall the project has substantially
            impacted the quality and relevance of engineering education,
            but only had a limited impact on secondary technical
            schools. No evidence exists yet to show that program quality
            improvements have translated into better labor market
            absorption of graduates or better paying jobs. Thus, it is
            too early to measure the impact on the productive capacity
            of the economy, the ultimate goal of the project. The most
            pertinent of the lessons learned include the following: The
            competitive grants program used for the engineering
            education programs was an effective mechanism to bring about
            quality improvements in universities. The World Bank must
            ensure that government regulations do not conflict with
            procedures for implementing project activities, and that
            joint planning with Government entities are completed during
            project preparation. Project start-up was delayed because of
            financing for project activities prior to effectiveness.
            That government procurement methods and Bank Standard
            Bidding Documents should be discussed prior to effectiveness
            supports the recent decision by the Bank to require a
            detailed procurement plan and manual prior to effectiveness.
            Project objectives were clear and consistent with the
            Government strategy for improving engineering and technical
            education. Projects that are a part of a broader strategy of
            reform pursued by the Government can be a catalyst leading
            to a full reform program. A full-time project management
            team is key.

728341.trustfund:
TF028065-CANADIAN CONSLT. COOP. PROGRAM,TF022221-CANADIAN CTF FOR SUSTAINABLE DEV-GENERAL,TF020765-CANADIAN 'GENERAL'
            CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF031680-EGYPT - HUMAN RESOURCES

repnme.cdata!: Egypt - Engineering and Technical Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed project focuses on
            strengthening Egypt's engineering and technical
            education under the Ministry of Higher Education. The
            objectives of the proposed project are: (a) to improve the
            quality and occupational relevance of university engineering
            education; and (b) to improve the quality of secondary and
            post-secondary technical education. To achieve these
            objectives, the project would comprise the following
            components: (a) an Engineering Education Development Program
            providing upgrading of facilities, laboratory equipment,
            instructional materials, and staff development to move
            existing university engineering faculties toward a more
            applied orientation through stronger linkages with industry,
            more relevant curricula and better qualified teaching staff;
            and (b) a Technical Teacher Education Program providing
            instructional equipment and technical assistance to initiate
            a new and reformed system for the professional preparation
            of high quality theory-cum-practice instructors to serve the
            secondary and post-secondary technical schools and
            institutes by establishing two new technical teacher
            training colleges.
